metadata.case_name: Appellant v. Sm. Nirmala Sundari Dassi & Anr.

facts.text: Sudhir Kumar Mitter was the owner of two houses, No. 86/1, Cornwallis Street and No. 7-C, Kirti Mitter Lane, Calcutta.
On May 19, 1934, Sudhir Kumar Mitter executed a mortgage for Rs. 3,000 over the said houses in favour of Sm. Nirmala Sundari Dassi.
Sm. Nirmala Sundari Dassi instituted Suit No. 158 of 1935 on this mortgage, and obtained a preliminary decree on March 8, 1935.
Registrar's report dated July 23, 1935 found that a sum of Rs. 3,914-6-6 was due to her, and on that, a final decree was passed on April 20, 1936.
No steps taken by first respondent to draw up the decree for nearly 18 years, as required under r. 27 of ch. 16 of the Original Side Rules of the Calcutta High Court.
On May 12, 1952, Sudhir Kumar Mitter sold both the houses to the appellant for Rs. 60,000, utilised largely for discharging prior mortgages, deed recites sold free of all encumbrances.
On February 17, 1954, first respondent obtained ex parte order under r. 27 to draw up and complete the decree.
On April 29, 1954, first respondent filed the final decree and commenced proceedings for sale of the mortgaged properties.
Sudhir Kumar Mitter objected before Registrar that execution was barred by limitation; Registrar made special report under ch. 26, r. 50.
P. B. Mukharji J. held execution not barred (Nirmala Sundari v. Sudhir Kumar, AIR 1955 Cal 484).
Sudhir Kumar Mitter preferred Appeal No. 152 of 1955 against that judgment, still pending.

On July 25, 1956, appellant applied to be brought on record as appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955, alleging purchase free of encumbrances, execution barred, Sudhir acting for her benefit but now colluding, seek substitution or addition.
Respondents opposed, stated settlement at Rs. 17,670 fair and binding on appellant.
Chakravarti C.J. and Lahiri J. dismissed application by order dated August 6, 1956.
Appellant applied under Art. 133 for leave to appeal, rejected as not final order and alternative prayer not pressed.
Appellant obtained special leave under Art. 136.
Respondents settled amount due at Rs. 17,670; affidavit details: Rs.7,200 interest at contract rate, Rs.5,000 costs in other suits, Rs.1,750 costs in proceedings.
Appellant contends amount under decree not exceed Rs.6,000, properties not liable for other costs.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant's application to be brought on record as appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955 is maintainable under O. 22, r. 10 or s. 146 of the Civil Procedure Code.
Whether on merits, the appellant should be allowed to be brought on record given substantial questions on limitation and amount due.

petitioner_arguments.text: Application maintainable under O. 22, r. 10 CPC as suit pending until decree drawn up in 1954, transfer on May 12, 1952 prior thereto.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: O. 22, r. 10 CPC; Lakshan Chunder Dey v. Sm. Nikunjamani Dassi (1923) 27 C.W.N. 755

petitioner_arguments.text: Alternatively, maintainable under s. 146 CPC as claiming under second respondent.
Execution barred by limitation; amount under decree not exceed Rs. 6,000; properties not liable for extraneous costs; settlement does not bind purchaser.

respondent_arguments.text: Not maintainable under O. 22, r. 10 as no application in original court during suit pendency; transfer prior to appeal filing.
Settlement at Rs. 17,670 fair, bona fide, binding on appellant.
s. 146 only for initiating proceedings, not continuing existing appeal.

court_reasoning.text: Not maintainable under O. 22, r. 10 as transfer not during pendency of appeal.
Application falls within s. 146 CPC; appeal is a proceeding; 'claiming under' includes assignment; entitled to continue appeal filed by assignor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 146 beneficent provision, to be construed liberally; cited precedents approve.

court_reasoning.text: On merits, substantial questions: limitation, amount due (Rs.6,000 vs Rs.17,670 including extraneous costs); appellant vitally interested as purchaser for value free of encumbrances.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Justice requires opportunity to protect rights; P.B. Mukharji J. noted substantial questions.

holdings.text: Appellant's application maintainable under s. 146 CPC to be brought on record as additional appellant.
Set aside High Court order; direct appellant be brought on record in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lakshan Chunder Dey v. Sm. Nikunjamani Dassi
precedents_cited.relevance: Suit pending until decree drawn up.
Appeal is proceeding under s.146; 'claiming under' includes devolution/assignment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jugalkishore Saraf v. Raw Cotton Co., Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Transferee entitled under s.146 even if not under specific rules.
Assignee can continue execution by transferor.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs right to be brought on record as claiming under; allows continuation of appeal.

statutes_cited.name: Original Side Rules of Calcutta High Court
statutes_cited.relevance: Drawing up decree; special report on limitation.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal rejected; special leave granted.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside Calcutta High Court order dated August 6, 1956 dismissing appellant's application, and directed that appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955 pending before High Court.
outcome.relief_granted: Brought on record as additional appellant.

key_quotes.text: "Section 146 provides that save as otherwise provided by the Code, any proceeding which can be taken by a person may also be taken by any person claiming under him."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "That section was introduced ... with the object of facilitating the exercise of rights by persons in whom they come to be vested by devolution or assignment, and being a beneficent provision should be construed liberally."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is obvious that there are several substantial questions arising for determination in which the appellant as purchaser of the properties is vitally interested, and indeed is the only person interested."
key_quotes.speaker: court
